summary.text:
**Clarifying JSON structure**

I need to produce a JSON object with specific keys, including summary_md, one_line_summary, highlights, and next_questions. The developer requested that I include 1–3 citations to the files I relied on, but the final format only specifies those four keys. While there's been mention of including citations before, the most recent update doesn’t include this requirement. I think the best approach might be to incorporate the citations as a brief inline phrase in summary_md.

**Structuring summary in JSON**

I'm matching what we did in previous rounds. I need to ensure that summary_md has a maximum of 200 words, one_line_summary is under 100 characters, and highlights contain 3–7 concise strings. The summary will include key findings like MST_log(L∞) being less than or equal to Reg_log, and mention norm lifting with a constant factor, as well as a worst-case gap of Θ(log n). I also want to include citations in summary_md. I'll keep everything concise and valid according to the JSON structure.

**Generating final JSON**

I’m ready to produce the final JSON. The summary_md will be around 120 words and will detail how we proved MST_log(π) is less than or equal to Reg_log(π) for the L∞ norm using Kruskal’s integral identity and a sparse threshold graph. I’ll mention norm equivalence and the yield results for residue-class permutations. The worst-case multiplicative gap will also be highlighted. I’ll ensure to include the sources and keep the highlights and next questions concise before returning the JSON format only.

content.text: {"summary_md":"Using Kruskal’s integral identity and a sparse threshold graph H(t) we proved MST_log(π) ≤ Reg_log(π) for the L∞ norm; norm equivalence lifts this to MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) for any fixed norm. Residue-class (mod-m) permutations (parity as m=2) give MST_log=Θ(n) but Reg_log=Θ(n log n), so Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n) and no universal constant reverses the inequality. A per-edge lower bound on MST yields Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/c_N)·MST_log^N(π) with explicit c_N for common norms, so the worst-case multiplicative gap is Θ(log n) and is tight. Sources: Research Notes; Current Proofs.","one_line_summary":"MST_log ≤ C·Reg_log; reverse fails — worst-case gap Θ(log n).","highlights":["Kruskal-integral + sparse H(t) gives MST_log^{∞}(π) ≤ ∑_i log(1+min(Δ_i,t_i)) ≤ Reg_log(π).","Norm lifting: for any fixed norm N, MST_log^N(π) ≤ C_N·Reg_log(π) (C_N from operator-norm bound).","Mod-m (parity) permutations yield MST_log=Θ(n) and Reg_log=Θ(n log n) ⇒ Reg_log/MST_log=Θ(log n).","Universal reverse bound: Reg_log(π) ≤ (log(1+n)/c_N)·MST_log^N(π) with explicit c_N (L∞,L2,L1).","Therefore the worst-case multiplicative gap between the measures is Θ(log n), and this factor is tight."],"next_questions":["Compute/optimize best constants C_N and c_N for L1,L2,L∞.","Determine leading constants/asymptotics for E[MST_log] and E[Reg_log] under uniform random π.","Search for (or rule out) permutation families with separation larger than Θ(log n)."]}

one_line_summary.description: Brief one-line summary for UI display
one_line_summary.title: One Line Summary
